EasyLesson.Message:
Message 1 of 5

The atom is the building block of all matter.  It is composed of three parts.

At the center, is the nucleus.  It contains protons and neutrons.

Message 2 of 5

Around the nucleus are electron orbitals (paths) that contain electrons.

These orbitals can have complex 3D shapes, but here they are represented as circles.

Message 3 of 5

In the image shown, there are two orbitals, one is the inner ring, the second is the outer ring.

The electrons that sit in these orbitals spin around the nucleus and have very important properties.

Message 4 of 5

The most important property for this lesson is that electron can jump  between orbitals (from one ring to another).

Message 5 of 5

When energy is applied to the atom, the electron moves from the lowest to highest orbital, trapping that energy for a short time. Press Exit and locate the experiment stage.

MediumLesson.Message:
Message 1 of 5

The atom is the building block of all matter.  It is composed of three parts.

At the center, is the nucleus.  It contains positively charged protons and neutrons which carry no charge.

Message 2 of 5

Around the nucleus are negatively charged particles called electrons that orbit in patterns set by their mathematical properties.

Message 3 of 5

The simplest orbital, the s orbital, has a spherical shape and is represented here as a circle.

Shown are the two lowest energy orbitals of helium, 1s and 2s.

Message 4 of 5

The most important property for this lesson is that electrons can transition (jump) between orbitals (from one ring to another).

Message 5 of 5

When energy is applied to the atom, the electron is excited from the 1s to the 2s orbital for a short period of time.

Press Exit and locate the experiment stage.

HardLesson.Message:
Message 1 of 5

The atom is the building block of all matter.  It is composed of three parts.

At the center, is the nucleus.  It contains positively charged protons and neutrons which carry no charge.

Message 2 of 5

 Around the nucleus, there are negatively charged electrons that orbit in patterns set by their quantum mechanical properties.

Message 3 of 5

 Shown here are the two lowest s orbitals of He, 1s and 2s.  Only the 1s is populated with electrons in the ground state.

Message 4 of 5

Electrons can transition between the orbitals when energy is applied.

Message 5 of 5

When energy is applied to the system, the electron is excited from the 1s to the 2s energy level.

The 2s orbital is only populated for a short period of time, after which the electron returns to the ground state.

Press Exit and locate the experiment stage.
